questions.text: On clinical examination, you noticed the peripheral rim of the iris is present and Zonules of the lens and ciliary processes. What is your provisional diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

CLINICAL ANIRIDIA CONGENITAL ANIRIDIA (IRIDREMIA) It refers to the congenital absence of iris. True aniridia,i.e., complete absence of the iris is extremely rare. Usually, a peripheral rim of the iris is present and this condition is called ‘Clinical aniridia'. Zonules of the lens and ciliary processes are often visible. The condition is usually familial and may be associated with glaucoma due to angle anomalies.

questions.text: A 1-year child comes with the below presentation, and other investigation shows that she also suffered from dermoid cyst, which is the most common cause of this deformity?

options.label: A
options.text: Reduction of malformation during the closure of the optic cup

options.label: C
options.text: Horizontal shortening of the palpebral fissure

options.label: D
options.text: Partial fusion between the upper and lower eyelids

questions.correct_answer: A. Reduction of malformation during the closure of the optic cup
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Reduction of malformation during the closure of the optic cup A normally unilateral triangular eyelid defect with its base at the margin of the eyelid occurring most often in the upper eyelid → Congenital coloboma results from a reduction in malformation during the closure of the optic cup in the embryonic stage. The disorder is often accompanied by additional deformities such as dermoid cysts or microphthalmos. - shortening of the horizontal palpebral fissure without pathologic changes in the eyelids → Blepharophimosis -horizontal shortening of the palpebral fissure with a fusion of the eyelids at the lateral and medial angles of the eye → Ankyloblepharon Limbal dermoid and coloboma

Highyeild:

Coloboma of the lid This is a notch in the edge of the lid. The gap is usually situated on the inner side of the midline, generally affecting the upper lid, but two or more defects may occur in the same lid. Sometimes a bridge of skin links the coloboma to the globe, or there is a dermoid astride the limbus at the site of the coloboma. There are often other congenital defects of the eye or other parts of the body such as coloboma of the iris or accessory auricles. Some cases are due to incomplete closure of the embryonic facial cleft, and others are probably due to the pressure of amniotic bands. Occasionally there is a notch at the outer part of the lower lid, associated with maldevelopment of the first visceral arch (mandibulofacial dysostosis, Goldenhar syndrome).

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B. Malformation of the tarsal palate - not the correct option. Option: C. Horizontal shortening of the palpebral fissure - this is not responsible for a dermoid cyst. Option: D. Partial fusion between the upper and lower eyelids - not the cause of the above finding.

questions.correct_answer: C. Incomplete COLOBOMA affects pupil-to-optic disc
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Incomplete COLOBOMA affects pupil-to-optic disc CONGENITAL COLOBOMA OF THE UVEAL TRACT Congenital coloboma (absence of tissue) of the iris, ciliary body, and choroid may be seen in association or independently. Coloboma may be typical or atypical.

Highyeild:

CONGENITAL COLOBOMA OF THE UVEAL TRACT Congenital coloboma (absence of tissue) of the iris, ciliary body, and choroid may be seen in association or independently. Coloboma may be typical or atypical . Typical coloboma is seen in the inferonasal quadrant and occurs due to defective closure of the embryonic fissure. Typical coloboma may be complete or incomplete . Complete coloboma extends from the pupil to the optic nerve, with a sector-shaped gap occupying about one-eighth of the circumference of the retina, choroid, ciliary body, and iris and causes a corresponding indentation of the lens where the zonular fibers are missing . Incomplete coloboma may involve the iris alone, or the iris and ciliary body (more common), or the iris, ciliary body, and part of the choroid (i.e. stops short of the optic nerve). 2. Atypical coloboma is occasionally found in other positions. It is usually incomplete.

questions.text: A 5 year old child presents with the following finding. Which one of the following is a characteristic of this condition?

options.label: A
options.text: This disease is secondary to an inflammatory process.

questions.explanation:
Solution:

This process is nonprogressive. The given case history and findings point towards the diagnosis of Sclerocornea Sclerocornea is a congenital anomaly of the eye in which the cornea blends with the sclera, having no clear-cut boundary. The extent of the resulting opacity varies from peripheral to total ( sclerocornea totalis)

Highyeild:

ANOMALIES OF CORNEAL TRANSPARENCY A normal cornea is a transparent structure. A few congenital conditions in which corneal transparency is disturbed are as given below: Anterior embryotoxic. It is characterized by congenitally broad limbus superiorly. Posterior embryotoxic. It refers to the thickening and anterior displacement of Schwalbe's Line. Congenital corneal opacity. Corneal opacity, i.e. scarring of corneal stroma, is often an acquired condition but has been reported to occur congenitally in isolation and also in association with Lowe's syndrome, Axenfeld's anomaly, Rieger's syndrome, and Peter's anomaly. Sclerocornea refers to a sclera-like cloudy cornea, which may be peripheral or diffuse. Dermoids usually occur at the inferotemporal limbus and are round, dome-shaped, and pink to white to yellow in color. Rarely the dermoids may involve a large area of the cornea, the entire limbus, the entire cornea, or even the interior of the eye. Differential diagnosis of neonatal/cloudy cornea . The acronym 'STUMPED' helps to remember the common conditions to be included in the differential diagnosis of the neonatal cloudy cornea. The conditions are as follows: Sclerocornea Tears in Descemet's membrane Ulcer Metabolic conditions Posterior corneal defect Endothelial dystrophy Dermoid.
